div1.p: Herrera writes about his examination of the patient in Colima, Mexico, whose death was diagnosed as possibly being from yellow fever and states his opinion that the man suffered from malaria complicated by alcoholism.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Jose M. Herrera to H. B. Richardson, August 22, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]
div1.opener:
COPY
Translated from the Spanish, HRM
9-6-23
HRM
DUPLICATE
Colima, Col.,
August 22, 1923.
Mr. H. B. Richardson,
Colima, Col.
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to the conversation which I had with you this
morning at my office, I have the honor to present the following report:

On Sunday, August 19, 1923, I was called to attend a patient
at number 451 Helisario Dominguez Calle of this City. There I found a man
about 28 years of age, with normal complexion, who, according to what I was
told, had been sick for six days without medical attention. On that day he
had taken a saline purgative causing numerous evacuations which alarmed the
patient and his family, who decided to call for a doctor. I had the op-
portunity of seeing one of these evacuations and noted that it was very
yellow, fetid, with some intestinal mucus and small traces of blood. His
pulse was weak, frequent (130 per minute), his temperature was 38 C. His
abdomen soft to palpation; by this diagnostic method I found the liver and
spleen slightly enlarged; his heart showed no apparent organic lesion,
regular, and its action corresponded to the pulsations already mentioned;
his mentality was in perfect condition; his tongue was humid, dirty and of
uniform color; his gums were also of uniform color; they did not show any
modifications along the edges. While with the patient, the latter did not
complain of any trouble other than that caused by the evacuations and by
the weakened condition of which he said to be suffering. The patient him-
-2-
self informed me that at the beginning of the disease he had suffered
with pains in the abdomen and legs, moderate fever from the very start
of the disease, with increase in the severity of the symptoms on each
third day. According to what I was told, this patient lived in Man-
zanillo and had a history of malaria and alcoholism.

As you will note by this report, I do not pretend to make
a clinical history. It is impossible to do so with only one examina-
tion of the patient as I was not consulted any more. I desire to fur-
nish this data to you in case they should be of any use to you, since
I have been told that this patient died a few days ago and that his
death is attributed to yellow fever. My diagnosis was that of malaria
in an alcoholic individual.
